awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC: Early-Stage Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Collaborative: Advances in Socio-Algorithmic Information Diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Social media now play an important role in exposing people to information about a wide range of topics ranging from entertainment to hard news and political debate. What can be seen on these platforms is heavily influenced by algorithms that are designed to select the most engaging and relevant content for each user. By seeking to maximize engagement, these algorithms may inadvertently amplify factually dubious or poor quality information that reinforces users' existing beliefs. In doing so, these algorithms could reduce the diversity of information to which users are exposed. This project will develop new content recommendation algorithms that reduce this risk and improve the quality and diversity of information circulating on social media.

This research will develop an understanding of how coupled cyber-human systems process information in the context of news consumption on social media. This context creates important information-processing vulnerabilities at the social, behavioral, cognitive, and algorithmic levels. Using data from a nationally representative sample of the U.S. population, investigators will measure the association between political attitudes, readership, engagement, and information quality. They will also test the effect of behavioral nudges designed to promote the consumption of diverse information in a browser extension/smartphone app. Finally, the researchers will develop a generic modeling framework to evaluate the effect of these recommendations on audience-slant diversification and to test their robustness against fraudulent (shilling) attacks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the relationship between the political diversity of the audience for online information sources (partisan diversity) and the quality of the news and information that those sources produce (news reliability). We specifically tested whether partisan diversity is associated with greater news reliability and whether taking partisan audience diversity into account in algorithmic recommendations would increase the reliability of the news that people see through social media.

Our first study examines a large anonymized dataset of paired survey and online behavior data provided by consenting participants. These data allow us to examine the partisanship of the people who visit various websites. In an article published in Nature Human Behaviour, we report two key results. First, websites with greater partisan diversity (and less extreme audiences) have higher levels of reliability. Second, incorporating audience diversity into a recommendation algorithm increases the reliability of the news that is recommended to users with only slight costs in recommendation relevance (as measured by our ability to predict the websites that users will actually visit using standard metrics of ranking accuracy). These findings suggest that incorporating partisan diversity into news recommendations could increase the reliability of news on social media. 

For a second study, we developed a research platform that replicates the experience of scrolling a social media news feed that has been ranked according to one of several ranking methods (e.g., chronological, by popularity, by audience diversity, etc.). This platform records all engagements and impressions, giving us a complete picture of user-content interactions. We additionally integrate the platform with the Twitter API to ensure the content inventory is realistic. Users log into the platform using their own Twitter credentials, which allows us to pull content from their home timeline, making it possible to test the effect of counterfactual rankings on the same content that users would normally see on their Twitter feed. Similarly, if the user decides to engage with content shown on the platform (for example, by retweeting or liking a tweet), the action is pushed back to Twitter, ensuring that content engagement decisions parallel the interactions they have with content on their own Twitter feed.

The second study will vary the information recommended to consenting participants. We will examine the effect of rankings that take partisan audience diversity into account on two behavioral outcomes: (i) news exposure as measured via content impressions and feed telemetry data and (ii) news engagement as measured via the information participants that consume (click) or engage with (like or retweet). To do so, our experiment will randomly assign people to view content ranked via different methods. This experimental design will allow us to test whether recommendations from an algorithm that takes audience partisanship into account will expose people to more politically diverse and reliable sources of information. We will also test the effects of these rankings on engagement rates as well as the reliability of news and information that people view or engage with.
